articles.headline: An S.L.R. Tailored for Video
articles.snippet: Panasonic shrinks a single-lens reflex camera by removing the mirror box. And the GH1 arrives, breaking down technological barriers.
articles.abstract: Panasonic shrinks a single-lens reflex camera by removing the mirror box. And the GH1 arrives, breaking down technological barriers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Panasonic’s Lumix G1 digital camera arrived last fall, it was a technical breakthrough that took a giant stride toward the holy grail of photography: gorgeous, professional-looking photos from a small camera. It was Popular Photography’s Camera of the Year, and it made plenty of hearts race.

articles.headline: Chrysler Bankruptcy Looms as Deal on Debt Falters
articles.snippet: Barring an agreement that looked increasingly difficult, Chrysler was expected to seek Chapter 11 protection on Thursday.
articles.abstract: Barring an agreement that looked increasingly difficult, Chrysler was expected to seek Chapter 11 protection on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Last-minute efforts by the Treasury Department to win over recalcitrant Chrysler debtholders failed Wednesday night, setting up a near-certain bankruptcy filing by the American automaker, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.byline: By Zachery Kouwe and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: A Little Give and Take on Electricity
articles.snippet: Smart consumers use energy in their houses based on minute-to-minute price fluctuations, saving money.
articles.abstract: Smart consumers use energy in their houses based on minute-to-minute price fluctuations, saving money.

articles.headline: Bringing Efficiency to the Infrastructure
articles.snippet: Environmentally friendly systems help to manage roads, rails and food distribution with low-cost sensors and clever software for analytics and visualization.
articles.abstract: Environmentally friendly systems help to manage roads, rails and food distribution with low-cost sensors and clever software for analytics and visualization.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the mid-1990s, the Internet took off because its technological time had come. Years of steady progress in developing more powerful and less expensive computers, Web software and faster communications links finally came together.

articles.headline: Name Hurts Main Unit of A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The name American International Underwriters is just too close to American International Group.
articles.abstract: The name American International Underwriters is just too close to American International Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Less than two months after changing its name, the biggest and best-known unit of American International Group is preparing to change its name again, in the latest sign of damage to one of the world’s most famous brands.

articles.headline: As Detroit Is Remade, the U.A.W. Stands to Gain
articles.snippet: The union could gain significant shares of General Motors and Chrysler, giving it a voice in the companies’ futures.
articles.abstract: The union could gain significant shares of General Motors and Chrysler, giving it a voice in the companies’ futures.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In the devastating slump that has forced one of Detroit’s automakers into bankruptcy and another to the edge of it, the United Automobile Workers union stands to become one of the industry’s few winners.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Radio Giant Faces Crisis in Cash Flow
articles.snippet: Clear Channel, the radio station operator that was taken private last year, is facing mounting debt payments as media companies face a steep drop in advertising.
articles.abstract: Clear Channel, the radio station operator that was taken private last year, is facing mounting debt payments as media companies face a steep drop in advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is too soon to say who will be the biggest loser among media companies in this recession. But Clear Channel Communications is vying for the title.

articles.headline: Credentials Challenged, Radical Quotes West Point
articles.snippet: Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a theorist of jihad, defended his hard-line credentials by citing Western analysts.
articles.abstract: Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a theorist of jihad, defended his hard-line credentials by citing Western analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — He has been mentor to some of the most brutal terrorists on earth. But Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a prominent cleric and theorist of jihad living in Jordan, has grown tired of hearing younger extremists accuse him of going soft.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Debate: A Broader Party or a Purer One?
articles.snippet: Republicans are debating how to rebuild the party in the wake of Senator Arlen Specter’s departure.
articles.abstract: Republicans are debating how to rebuild the party in the wake of Senator Arlen Specter’s departure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A fundamental debate broke out among Republicans on Wednesday over how to rebuild the party in the wake of Senator Arlen Specter’s departure: Should it purge moderate voices like Mr. Specter and embrace its conservative roots or seek to broaden its appeal to regain a competitive position against Democrats?
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Chrysler Files to Seek Bankruptcy Protection
articles.snippet: President Obama forced Chrysler into federal bankruptcy protection on Thursday so it could pursue a lifesaving alliance with the Italian automaker Fiat.
articles.abstract: President Obama forced Chrysler into federal bankruptcy protection on Thursday so it could pursue a lifesaving alliance with the Italian automaker Fiat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama forced Chrysler into federal bankruptcy protection on Thursday so it could pursue a lifesaving alliance with the Italian automaker Fiat, in yet another extraordinary intervention into private industry by the federal government.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Motorola Scrambles to Restore Its Lost Cellphone Glory
articles.snippet: Industry analysts are questioning not whether Motorola will again become dominant but whether the handset division will survive.
articles.abstract: Industry analysts are questioning not whether Motorola will again become dominant but whether the handset division will survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Motorola has had its ups and downs. Fifteen years ago, a gray brick Motorola handset was synonymous with mobile phone. Sales slipped, but the company came back five years ago with the sleek Razr, the must-have cellphone.
